## With Typeform, you can ‚Ä®customize everything

### Branding

Change text, colors, and even logos to match the look and feel of your brand. Then embed forms smoothly onto web and email.

### Experience

Make forms feel effortless to fill out. Pace questions, call people by their name, and adapt the flow based on the data they share.

### Integrations

Stay efficient by connecting forms to your workflow. Typeform integrates with 300+ tools including Slack, Zapier, and HubSpot.

![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/66ffe2174aa8e8d5661c2708/671a8121cfab40f53733710e_3e2ca1b7c4134bff047e46aaab0c9d28_b2c%20branding.webp)

![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/66ffe2174aa8e8d5661c2708/67336e5417e4a4b719d407b5_typeform-logic-jumps-desktop.webp)

![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/66ffe2174aa8e8d5661c2708/67336e61745666127d192f81_typeform-integrations.webp)

Customer satisfaction survey template¬†FAQs:

### 10 customer satisfaction survey questions to include

You have to be on top of your customer service‚Äîalways. But to start improving, you need to know where to begin.

Send out a customer satisfaction survey to see where you stand with your CSAT. Turn detractors into your biggest fans by showing them that you can do better‚Äîbut don‚Äôt forget to reward your brand‚Äôs fan club too.

Okay, not everyone is going to become a promoter for your brand. But at least by opening a conversation, you‚Äôre doing everything you possibly can to discover and improve your Net Promoter Score¬Æ.

Use these **top customer satisfaction survey questions** to find out what your customers are _really_ thinking:

01. How often do you use our product?
02. What do you use us for the most?
03. What's your favorite thing about our service?
04. If you could change one thing, what would it be?
05. How likely are you to recommend us to a friend?
06. What should we do next to make you smile?
07. Was there anything that nearly stopped you signing up?
08. If our product dissapeared tomorrow‚Äîhow would you feel?
09. How easy was it to use/buy our product?
10. Do you have any other comments to add? Or a joke?

### How to write great customer satisfaction survey questions

Sure, you can use the most popular questions above. But sometimes, you need to go a little deeper. And if you do, here's some tips on how to succeed with the right questions‚Äîwithout being biased or offending anyone.

### Let people skip questions

Sometimes people just don‚Äôt know‚Äîand that‚Äôs absolutely fine. How can Katy answer the question ‚Äúhow did our store smell today?‚Äù, when she was completely blocked up with a cold and only dashed in for some lemon and honey?

When people are presented with questions they don‚Äôt know the answer to, they usually desert the online survey completely. We‚Äôve all done it.

Avoid this by letting people skip a question if they don‚Äôt want to fill it in, or by adding a simple ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know‚Äù response. Your customer satisfaction survey isn‚Äôt a test and by putting customer experience first, you'll only improve your CSAT.

### Avoid influencing people

We‚Äôve all filled out cheesy customer survey questions which are completely biased towards the company.

‚ÄúHow were our _amazing customer success team_ today?‚Äù‚ÄîActually not so great, Dave hung up on me.

‚ÄúWas it easy to find things in our organized aisles?‚Äù‚ÄîNo, it looked like someone had let a few bears loose.

‚ÄúWho made your visit extra special today?‚Äù‚ÄîI‚Äôd say it was Karen, she smashed my eggs while scanning them.

If you‚Äôre asking questions like these, you‚Äôre going to be left with a load of useless answers‚Äîand a few replies from trolls.

Instead of asking ‚ÄúHow were our _superstar team_ today?‚Äù, sack the superlatives and ask, ‚Äúdid our team resolve your problem?‚Äù

Let every customer tell their own story, and listen very carefully.

### Remember that timing is crucial

Generally, the sooner you send the survey, the better. Are you going to strike while when the order form has been processed or wait till the product lands in their hands?

Segmenting your users is essential before sending out your customer satisfaction survey‚Äîand timing is all.

Ask how people‚Äôs shopping experience was within 24 hours and it will still be fresh in their minds. Any later and they‚Äôll probably have forgotten, unless it was awful‚Äîlooking at you Karen, put those eggs away.

Likewise, find out how the shipping process was after the package has hit the doormat, and not a minute earlier.

### Never forget your goal

You want to find out how happy your customers are. You‚Äôre not trying to do market research for a new product just yet, so don‚Äôt be tempted to veer off course.

Every survey you send out should have a clear goal. Before you even start putting the blocks of your typeform together, think:

1. Who are these customer survey questions for?
2. What are we actually asking?
3. How are we going to use this information?

If you can‚Äôt answer these questions, take a breather and rethink your customer satisfaction survey plan. Go for a walk, catch-up with your dog‚Äîor start planning how to build a [barception](https://www.typeform.com/blog/inside-story/barception/).

### Talk like, well, a human

Robots haven‚Äôt taken over our jobs _yet_, so don‚Äôt start acting like one. Engage people by creating a customer feedback survey that mirrors a conversation.

Turn ‚Äúusers‚Äù into people. Ask questions as you would if you were speaking‚Äîditch any jargon or formalities. Say hello, ask their name, and why not add a Thank You screen with a discount code on their next purchase? They‚Äôre doing you a big favor.

It‚Äôs the little things that make the difference and will take your business from _meh_ to **YEH**.

### Don't create questions to reach a "limit"

As long as you‚Äôre writing a customer satisfaction survey that will give you the information you need, don‚Äôt get too worked up over the number of questions.

Some people say 10 questions is the optimum number. Others warn you not to go over 20 questions. Sometimes, even one Likert scale question can do the job. It really depends‚Äîbut as a rule of thumb, the shorter a customer satisfaction survey is, the better.

52% of people said they wouldn‚Äôt complete a survey if it took them over 3 minutes. We close more surveys than we complete, so keep it short and sweet.

Make it simple for people to whizz through your customer satisfaction survey and you‚Äôll end up with a higher response rate. And that means you can really start concentrating on how to give the best service ever and increase your customer loyalty.

### How to measure customer satisfaction

It's a weird thing, isn't it? _Measuring_ how happy your customers are.

A customer satisfaction survey is the best way to get real, honest feedback into your inbox about your business. But there are other methods you should be using too to complement your CSAT online survey.

- Keep an eye on social media and make use of online listening tools that are available
- Talk to your customers‚Äîinvite them in for a coffee or lunch and discover how your product/service helps them
- Send out regular satisfaction surveys‚Äîalternate between longer surveys and 'on-the-pulse' one question [polls](https://www.typeform.com/examples/polls/)
- Set up Net Promoter Score¬Æ tracking‚Äîthen share it with your team weekly so everyone knows what your CSAT is looking like
- Analyze your survey responses and findings all the time‚Äîcan you see anything that comes up over and over again? Remember to follow-up with your users too

primary.reasoning: Button #1 ('Start with this template') has a dark background color (#2A222B) with vibrant text color (#FAF9FB), making it stand out as the main call-to-action. It is action-oriented and clearly indicates the primary action the user should take.

secondary.reasoning: Button #0 ('Preview template') has a light background color (#FAF9FB) which is different from the primary button's dark color. It serves as a secondary action that is less prominent than the primary CTA, making it suitable as the secondary button.

personality.targetAudience: business professionals and organizations looking to improve customer satisfaction

questions.help_text: Great for honing in on specific things to improve
questions.question_text: How often do you use our product?

questions.help_text: Great for honing in on specific things to improve
questions.question_text: What do you use us for the most?

questions.help_text: Great for honing in on specific things to improve
questions.question_text: What's your favorite thing about our service?

questions.help_text: Great for honing in on specific things to improve
questions.question_text: If you could change one thing, what would it be?

questions.help_text: Great for honing in on specific things to improve
questions.question_text: How likely are you to recommend us to a friend?

questions.help_text: Great for honing in on specific things to improve
questions.question_text: What should we do next to make you smile?

questions.help_text: Great for honing in on specific things to improve
questions.question_text: Was there anything that nearly stopped you signing up?

questions.help_text: Great for honing in on specific things to improve
questions.question_text: If our product disappeared tomorrow‚Äîhow would you feel?

questions.help_text: Great for honing in on specific things to improve
questions.question_text: How easy was it to use/buy our product?

questions.help_text: Great for honing in on specific things to improve
questions.question_text: Do you have any other comments to add? Or a joke?

survey_basics.title: Customer Satisfaction Survey
survey_basics.purpose: To gauge customer satisfaction and identify areas for improvement
survey_basics.description: A survey designed to collect feedback from customers regarding their satisfaction with our products and services.

sections.section_description: Questions aimed at understanding customer satisfaction and feedback.

ux_best_practices.description: Allow respondents to skip questions they don't know the answer to.
ux_best_practices.implementation: Include an option for 'I don't know' or allow skipping.

ux_best_practices.description: Ensure questions are unbiased and allow for honest feedback.
Send surveys soon after the customer experience.
ux_best_practices.implementation: Segment users and time surveys appropriately.

ux_best_practices.description: Have a clear purpose for the survey.
ux_best_practices.implementation: Define the target audience and objectives before creating the survey.

ux_best_practices.description: Engage respondents in a conversational tone.
ux_best_practices.implementation: Use friendly language and avoid jargon.

ux_best_practices.practice: Don't create questions to reach a 'limit'
ux_best_practices.description: Focus on the quality of questions rather than quantity.
ux_best_practices.implementation: Keep surveys concise to improve response rates.

ui_design_patterns.button_styles: Rounded buttons with clear calls to action
ui_design_patterns.question_per_page: One question per page for focus

scoring_and_analytics.interpretation_guidance: Analyze responses to identify trends and areas for improvement.

validated_scales_used.description: A scale used to measure attitudes or opinions on a range.

compliance_considerations.requirement: Ensure data privacy and user consent.
